author: nooobbbbtrader134
body: JNPR

author: Admirable_Nothing
body:
I was there.  3 hour commute each way over only 40 miles.  Everybody working.  Exodus, Adaptive Broadband, Cisco, Juniper, WebVan, Pets.com, Napster, Netscape, Palm, Sun Micro, Global Crossing and many others.

By 2002 that was an hour commute.  Luckily I still had a job.

author: alpha_beta_pruning
body:
Semis can be risky/volatile since they're affected by trade policy and the market performance of other sectors, but that also makes them a great long term investment. TSM has some of the best fabs in the world. You might also check 
MCHP, AMAT, or NXPI. Or check out LRCX since they build the hardware that then builds your hardware. :)

author: Jwceltic5
body:
I've been holding LRCX for a long time so hopefully I can give you some perspective. As the other reply stated, capex has actually been increasing. 

Sales has increased because the semiconductor equipment industry is extremely cyclical, where companies overspend on manufacturing equipment trying to meet demand every couple of years. LRCX has increased revenue by pivoting/focusing on DRAM and NAND, as well as expanding their services (repairs, maintenance, etc.) business that provides consistent cash flow. I believe that segment is now \~30% of revenue.

author: Jwceltic5
body: Some ideas for chipmakers - TSM, LRCX, KLAC

author: mechtech
body:
> I shorted the market when Apple initially reported supply chain problems back in early February and turned 15k into 130k

Hah, I did exactly the same thing. Turned 5k into 100k in an old brokerage account through Apple puts at the start of the crash. Once South Korea and Samsung facilities got hit with COVID I figured there would be (warranted) doomsday predictions about tech supply chains that would hit AAPL.

I did end up catching the bottom though in another account. SABR @ 3, CPRI @ 6, LEAPS on VTR @ 15. Those were the core buys when the market was at peak liquidation. That account was managed into a more balanced COVID-recovery portfolio. Still very heavy on SABR and CPRI.

Here are some of the current holdings: https://i.imgur.com/IAiV8gp.png. It's admittedly an absolute mess because it's all locked in a brokerage account that none of this should have taken place in. The market was literally down 10% and my main trading account was in a hilariously bad margin call while I was on the phone with someone asking "is the world ending", so the set of buys at market bottom were extremely haphazard and chaotic. Meanwhile, tech is my wheelhouse yet I happened to be about to pull the trigger on luxury clothing (which I know *absolutely* nothing about) because it's apparently trading at half of its bankruptcy value and buys needed to happen within a window of the next few minutes as the -10% market was turning. Just an absurd day. Things may have literally been on fire as far as my memory serves. Soon it will be in an IB portfolio margin account with proper management tools though.

So the path has been: Set of random equities and options from the SPY 2200 market bottom -> Scaling out of those positions and buying Quality/Tech (asml, lrcx, nok, sbux, oled , chl were the buys in the weeks after the bottom) -> Value COVID recovery/"return to normalcy" stocks (brk, bx, banks, txrh, cxw, vwagy, dfs, banks). There's also been some side ventures in there like buying CLMT and XOM during the negative oil event, and those won't be held long term.

Lots of options not showing there as well. Collars on positions, covered calls, 200k short nasdaq hedge. Basically locking in the profits and marching towards neutral until the positions can move over to the PM margin account and it can turn into something actually sane.

A lot of that stuff is probably going to be gone by next friday and sold into the rotation. dfs up 10% today, sabr up 12%, txrh up 8%, Well +7%, VTR +10%, CXW +6%... Today was the exact day that that list of stocks was positioned for. There was a 4 sigma move into value a few weeks ago that I took to be a canary in the coal mine for the rotation. Looked like a quake from quant funds moving factors around. Not sure what's next. It's probably time to focus on the insane quarterly reports we're about to get, and start actually paying attention to the real economy and things like the +600 unemployment checks rolling off and the unemployment trajectory. Maybe just step out of the way until that all picks trends.

There are still many laggards to pick out but they by and large have debt loads that carry a very real bankruptcy risk, and some extreme exposure to COVID and lockdowns (restaurants, entertainment, companies like SABR that provide the back-end for flight booking). So they come with a bundle of esoteric and disastrous tail risks, but honestly, some of the common risk exposures like consumer credit risk, commercial real estate, etc aren't rocket science to hedge against. Most of this stuff is not something I'd want to leave alone without watching charts for even a day though, even in a decently hedged portfolio.
